articles.headline: China’s Foreign Exchange Reserves Dwindling Rapidly
articles.snippet: China’s foreign-exchange reserves have shrunk by nearly a fifth since the summer of 2014, as Beijing has moved to shore up the value of its currency.
articles.abstract: China’s foreign-exchange reserves have shrunk by nearly a fifth since the summer of 2014, as Beijing has moved to shore up the value of its currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As markets around the world have churned, China has long taken comfort in having what in the financial world amounts to a life preserver: its vast holdings of other countries’ money.

articles.headline: SB Nation Removes Article Criticized as Sympathetic to Convicted Rapist
articles.snippet: The sports website said a long article about Daniel Holtzclaw, a former police officer convicted in a series of rapes, was “a complete failure.”
articles.abstract: The sports website said a long article about Daniel Holtzclaw, a former police officer convicted in a series of rapes, was “a complete failure.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after the sports website SB Nation published an article on Wednesday about Daniel Holtzclaw, a former Oklahoma City police officer convicted of raping multiple women, an editor who worked on the piece sent a laudatory email to a group of writers.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Daniel Victor

articles.headline: A Deal in the Dewey Case Still Leaves Troubling Questions
articles.snippet: While Zachary Warren, a former Dewey & LeBoeuf employee, will not face charges, the question remains why he was charged in the first place.
articles.abstract: While Zachary Warren, a former Dewey & LeBoeuf employee, will not face charges, the question remains why he was charged in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end of 2008, during the depths of the global financial crisis, two top officials at the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf invited a young colleague, Zachary Warren, to dinner at Del Frisco’s, a Midtown Manhattan restaurant. Mr. Warren was 24 years old, a couple of years out of Stanford and headed to law school at Georgetown in the fall.

articles.headline: Volkswagen Memos Suggest Company Misled U.S. Regulators
articles.snippet: Documents suggesting VW executives knew of elevated diesel emissions in early 2014 could create problems with regulators, car owners and stockholders.
articles.abstract: Documents suggesting VW executives knew of elevated diesel emissions in early 2014 could create problems with regulators, car owners and stockholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen internal memos and emails suggest that company executives pursued a strategy of delay and obfuscation with United States regulators after being confronted in early 2014 with evidence that VW diesel vehicles were emitting far more pollutants than allowed.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Appointment Could Reshape American Life
articles.snippet: An appointment by President Obama of a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia could set in motion a profound ideological shift on the court and create a new liberal majority.
articles.abstract: An appointment by President Obama of a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia could set in motion a profound ideological shift on the court and create a new liberal majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is a reason Republican senators are so adamant in their refusal to let President Obama appoint a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia, a towering figure in conservative jurisprudence. An Obama appointment would be the most consequential ideological shift on the court since 1991, creating a liberal majority that would almost certainly reshape American law and American life.

articles.headline: How Tim Cook, in iPhone Battle, Became a Bulwark for Digital Privacy
articles.snippet: As Apple’s products came to house more private information, the chief executive grew wary of prying eyes, leading to the standoff with the F.B.I.
articles.abstract: As Apple’s products came to house more private information, the chief executive grew wary of prying eyes, leading to the standoff with the F.B.I.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Letters from around the globe began pouring into the inbox of Timothy D. Cook not long after the publication of the first revelations from Edward J. Snowden about mass government surveillance.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Apple’s Line in the Sand Was Over a Year in the Making
articles.snippet: An operating system update with enhanced encryption technology in late 2014 set the stage to put Apple increasingly at odds with prosecutors seeking to unlock iPhones.
articles.abstract: An operating system update with enhanced encryption technology in late 2014 set the stage to put Apple increasingly at odds with prosecutors seeking to unlock iPhones.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Time and again after the introduction of the iPhone nearly a decade ago, the Justice Department asked Apple for help opening a locked phone. And nearly without fail, the company agreed.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Joseph Goldstein and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Donald Trump Fires Back at Sharp Rebuke by Pope Francis
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s attack on Francis reflected a political calculation that criticizing the pope will not hurt him with conservatives — and might even improve his standing in South Carolina.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s attack on Francis reflected a political calculation that criticizing the pope will not hurt him with conservatives — and might even improve his standing in South Carolina.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his most audacious attack yet on a revered public figure, Donald J. Trump veered into risky political territory on Thursday as he denounced Pope Francis, seeking to galvanize Republicans who worry about border security and appeal to evangelical voters who regard Francis as too liberal.

articles.headline: Race in Nevada, Once a Hillary Clinton Firewall, Is Now Hotly Contested
articles.snippet: After Mrs. Clinton’s narrow victory in Iowa and crushing defeat in New Hampshire, Nevada has turned into another tight and unpredictable contest.
articles.abstract: After Mrs. Clinton’s narrow victory in Iowa and crushing defeat in New Hampshire, Nevada has turned into another tight and unpredictable contest.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In a storefront on this city’s heavily Latino east side, the civil rights leader Dolores Huerta rallied a dozen volunteers for Hillary Clinton on Wednesday night, relating in Spanish a Mexican saying about people who go near a cactus only when it is bearing fruit.

articles.headline: Fighting Truancy Among India’s Teachers, With a Pistol and a Stick
articles.snippet: Manoj Mishra carries a pistol to defend himself as he fights a big obstacle to improving the largest primary school system in the world: absent teachers.
articles.abstract: Manoj Mishra carries a pistol to defend himself as he fights a big obstacle to improving the largest primary school system in the world: absent teachers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEORIA, India — The young man, having skipped school, was there to plead his case, but Manoj Mishra was having none of it. When the truant offered a letter from a relative of a government minister pleading for leniency, Mr. Mishra grabbed it and, with a frown, tore it in half and dropped it to the floor.

articles.headline: U.S. Bombing in Libya Reveals Limits of Strategy Against ISIS
articles.snippet: The strikes, which Western officials said targeted a senior operative linked to attacks in Tunisia, highlighted a growing gap in American military and diplomatic efforts.
articles.abstract: The strikes, which Western officials said targeted a senior operative linked to attacks in Tunisia, highlighted a growing gap in American military and diplomatic efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — American warplanes bombed a seaside town in Libya early Friday aiming to kill a militant commander linked to attacks on Western tourists. But the mission also highlighted the widening gap between American military operations and diplomatic efforts to bring peace and stability to a tumultuous region.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Ben Hubbard and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: In Nod to Law Enforcement in Apple Case, Obama Ends Attempt to Straddle Privacy Divide
articles.snippet: Technological advances in encryption made a clash between privacy and security inevitable, forcing him to take a side in the Apple case.
articles.abstract: Technological advances in encryption made a clash between privacy and security inevitable, forcing him to take a side in the Apple case.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, President Obama has struggled to reconcile a civil libertarian’s belief in personal privacy with a commander in chief’s imperatives for the nation’s security.
